p: World-wide zoonotic disease emergence is an increasing phenomenon due to environmental changes, ecological disturbances, and globalization [79]. The U.S. has already been affected by the emergence of WNV, recently identified a new zoonotic disease (Heartland virus) [80], [81], and is threatened by the spread of chikungunya virus to the Caribbean [76]. During the initial epidemics of WNV in the U.S. in 2002 and 2003, many mosquito control programs did not have a strong focus on Culex spp. mosquitoes. As knowledge of the WNV transmission system increased, vector control has improved by targeting Culex species to reduce human exposure events. The delay of Culex spp. vector control might have allowed more human WNV disease and may have contributed to the rapid spread of the virus across the U.S. highlighting the importance of a priori response strategies for potential viral threats.
